FacilityName: AHN North America, Inc. Heartland Ingredients
ParentCompanyName: Ajinomoto Health & Nutrition North America, Inc.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Facility and the Regulated Substance Handled

Ajinomoto Health & Nutrition North America  Heartland Ingredients is a manufacturer of feed grade Amino Acids and feed grade Algal Oil. Feed grade amino acids and feed grade Algal Oil are used in animal feed to improve the nutritional content of the animal feed. The amino acids and Algal Oil are manufactured using an industrial fermentation process. The primary raw material for the fermentation process is glucose, which is derived from corn. The amino acids are extracted, purified, and packaged for distribution throughout North America. Some products are exported to foreign countries. Algal Oil is extracted, separated, and packaged and distributed only in North America. 

Anhydrous ammonia, which is covered under the EPA Risk Management Plan, is used at the Heartland Ingredients facility. Ammonia is used for pH control in the fermentation process and in the extraction process of amino acids. 

The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at Our Facility

Ajinomoto Heartland Ingredients is committed to protecting our employees, the public, and the environment from the risks associated with the use of hazardous industrial chemicals, including anhydrous ammonia. 

We have taken steps to ensure that anhydrous ammonia is handled safely at our facility. Mechanical systems are inspected and tested to ensure safe and proper operations. Our employees are trained in the safe handling of ammonia and are required to take computer-based training and hands on. Approximately 12% of our employees have been trained to the HazMat Technician level, which allows quick response to any chemical release situation that may develop. 

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Regarding anhydrous ammonia, Heartland Ingredients is regulated under OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Program and EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP). Under these programs, we have developed and i

mplemented procedures, and we have installed equipment to help minimize the risk of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. These items include but are not limited too:
	Scheduled mechanical integrity testing of ammonia systems.
	Scheduled employee training on the hazards and safe handling of ammonia.
	Process safety information on anhydrous ammonia.
	Conducting process hazard analyses of the anhydrous ammonia systems.
	Written operating procedures for working with anhydrous ammonia.
	Management of change procedure for anhydrous ammonia systems.
	Conducting pre-start up safety reviews of new processes that use anhydrous ammonia.
	Conducting periodic compliance audits of our anhydrous ammonia systems.
	  Promptly investigating any anhydrous ammonia release incidents and recommending changes to prevent such incidents.
	Requiring employee participation in the development of safety programs.
	 Using hot work permits when conducting welding or cutting activities near anhydrous ammonia.
	Qualifying contractors used to work on anhydrous ammonia systems.
	Engineering and constructing anhydrous ammonia systems that are compliant with current engineering and industry standards.
	Administrative controls to prevent overfilling of anhydrous ammonia tanks. 
	Installation of ammonia leak sensors.
	Installation of remote switches for emergency shutdown of the anhydrous ammonia system. 
	Installation of a Deluge System above our anhydrous ammonia storage tanks.
	Installation of a secure fence around our anhydrous ammonia tanks.

The Five-Year Accident History
In the last five years, there have been no anhydrous ammonia releases at the Ajinomoto Health & Nutrition North America, Inc.  Heartland Ingredients facility that meet the criteria for a reportable release as specified in 40 CFR 68.42. 

The Emergency Response Program
In the event of a release of anhydrous ammonia, Ajinomoto Health & Nutrition North America, Inc.  Heartland Ingredients is prepared to res

pond. 

Procedures are in place to promptly alert our employees, contractors, public safety officials, the Iowa Department of Natural Resources (IDNR), and the National Response Center in the event of a hazardous material release. We have made preparations to have the necessary safety information available for all stakeholders in the event of an accidental hazardous material release. 

Ajinomoto Health & Nutrition North America, Inc.  Heartland Ingredients facility has coordinated with the Monroe County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and is included in the Monroe County Emergency Operations Plan (EOP). We have coordinated with the South East Iowa Response Group (Haz Mat Team) in Ottumwa, Iowa, located approximately 17 miles away, Mahaska County Emergency Management, and Eddyville fire department. 

Ajinomoto Health & Nutrition North America, Inc.  Heartland Ingredients employees have been trained on haz mat response, spill reporting, and notifying the necessary public safety authorities to alert the public. 

Ajinomoto Health & Nutrition North America, Inc.  Heartland Ingredients has the necessary equipment on site to deal with anticipated emergencies. Haz Mat Team employees have access to and are trained in the proper use of Class A fully contained encapsulated chemical suits with self-contained breathing equipment. If a Haz mat release escalates, our Monroe County 911 dispatch center can contact the Southeast Iowa Response Group (Haz Mat Team) in Ottumwa, Iowa for assistance. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Improving industrial chemical safety is a never-ending process. We are continuously striving to improve our safety practices at Ajinomoto Health & Nutrition North America, Inc.  Heartland Ingredients As changes in technology, techniques, or procedures present themselves, they will be examined and considered for implementation to improve the level of our safety as related to handling anhydrous ammonia.
